symp.939: Abnormal (high-pitched) breathing sounds, cough, coughing up blood, difficulty swallowing, persistent sore throat or hoarseness, neck pain, swelling in the neck, unintentional weight loss.
symp.94: Symptoms include painless loss of vision. The visual loss can present slowly with gradual vision loss over days to weeks.
symp.940: Pain with weight bearing, swelling, bruising, tenderness, decreased motion, and / or a feeling of instability. Often times many individuals may feel a distinct "pop" in their knee.
symp.941: Symptoms typically begin in childhood and consist of blinking, head jerking, shoulder shrugging, abnormal finger movements, yelling, hiccups, throat clearing, barking, touching themselves or other people, obscene gestures, repeating words or phrases, cursing.
symp.942: Pain in the vaginal area, swelling in the vaginal area, discharge, painful intercourse.
symp.943: Swollen red area of skin that is tender. The affected area is warm to the touch. There may be a white center and oozing of pus. Associated symptoms may include fatigue, fever, and nausea.
symp.944: Memory loss (dementia), personality changes, unsteady gait, incoordination, seizures, weakness, confusion, headaches, visual loss.
symp.945: Symptoms include diarrhea, foul-smelling stool, nausea, cramps, gas and indigestion.
symp.946: Leg swelling that becomes worse with standing. Leg pain, leg fullness, ulcers that do not heal (venous stasis ulcers), darkening and thickening of the skin, flaking skin, itchy skin, varicose veins.
symp.947: Symptoms tend to start with a runny nose and sore throat followed by a cough. The cough produces white, clear sputum. The mucous from the runny nose (rhinorrhea) is clear. Fever may be present although not as high as with other viral illnesses such as the flu. Muscle aches (myalgias) and headaches are common. The headache tends to be mild to moderate in severity.
symp.948: Eye redness, itching, irritation and discharge.
symp.949: Painful red mass, overlying skin is hard (induration), surrounding skin may be red, discharge from the mass, swollen armpit (auxiliary) lymph nodes.
symp.95: Back or neck pain, weakness, numbness, fever, skin redness.
symp.950: Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, tenderness, and decreased motion.
symp.951: Depends on the part of the body infected. Common symptoms include fever, pain, swelling, and fatigue.
symp.952: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain. The pain typically starts in the center of the abdomen then moves to the right lower side. Less frequently the pain is in other areas of the abdomen and even on the left side.
symp.953: Drunkenness, disinhibition, disorientation, drowsiness, lack of coordination, slurred speech, stupor, dizziness. Large ingestions can cause low body temperature (hypothermia) and other complications, including respiratory and cardiovascular collapse and death.
symp.954: Pain and swelling of the affected area. Many other symptoms can occur depending on the location of the cancer and whether the growth is damaging other organs. For example, sarcomas involving the lung can cause shortness of breath and/or chest pain; involvement of the abdomen can cause a blockage of the intestine resulting in vomiting and stomach pain.
symp.955: May cause no symptoms but may cause abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, infertility, irregular menstruation, painful intercourse, urinary frequency.
symp.956: Fever, sore throat, white discoloration of the tonsils (exudate), swollen lymph nodes, especially in the neck and armpit, general discomfort, uneasiness, or ill feeling, drowsiness, loss of appetite, muscle aches or stiffness, upper left abdominal discomfort, rash.
symp.957: Sensitivity to temperature or pressure. Sensitivity to cold food and drink is more common. Sensitivity to heat can be a more serious symptom.
symp.958: Bluish color to the skin (cyanosis), breathing problems, fatigue. The inherited type can cause stunted growth, mental retardation, seizures, and failure to thrive.
symp.959: Abdominal fullness, gaseous, abdominal distention, abdominal pain and cramping, vomiting, failure to pass gas or stool (severe constipation), diarrhea.
symp.96: Pain in the front and back of the shin, pain that is worse in the beginning of the exercise session, mild swelling of the front of the lower leg, pain with bending the toes or foot downward. If the disorder continues the pain may be present even when the patient is not exercising.
symp.960: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever, yellowing skin.
symp.961: Painful skin, skin redness, small pimples at the base of the hair follicle, red bumps around the hair follicles, increased warmth of the involved skin, itchy skin, skin swelling.
symp.962: The first symptoms are fever, nasal congestion, fatigue, muscle aches (myalgias) and headache. The rash appears 7 days later and first appears on the cheeks ("slapped cheeks") then spreads to the arms and legs 1 day later. The rash can have a "lacy" appearance. Other symptoms include fever, joint pain and a temporary anemia (low red blood cell count).
symp.963: Yellow skin, yellow discoloration of the white part of the eyes (sclera).
symp.964: Early symptoms involve muscle twitching followed by weakness. Muscle weakness involves the hands, arms, legs, and muscles of speech. Other affected areas cause problems swallowing, breathing difficulties, and slurred speech. Progressive weakness of the breathing muscles causes respiratory failure.
symp.965: Confusion, coma, incoordination, sleepiness, slurred speech, decreased respiratory effort.
symp.966: Palpitations, weakness, fainting, muscle twitching, constipation, paralysis.
symp.967: Symptoms may include tender, swollen lymph nodes, redness over the nodes, fever and limb swelling.
symp.968: Blood in the white part of the eye, minor eye discomfort may rarely be present.
symp.969: Palpitations, weakness, chest pain, shortness of breath, fainting, sudden death.
symp.97: Swelling of the eyelid, redness of the eyelid, a bump or pimple on the eyelid.
symp.970: Vaginal dryness, vaginal burning, painful intercourse, increased risk of urinary tract infections.
symp.971: Stiff muscles, shuffling walk, slow movements, difficulty initiating movement, a need to walk quickly to maintain balance, a feeling of frozen joints when you have not been moving, shaking or bobbing of the head or shaking of the hand, loss of facial expression, a tremulous voice, loss of fine motor skills, frequent falls, decline in intellectual function, constipation.
symp.972: Tremors, sweating, high blood pressure, racing heart, fever, confusion, hallucinations.
symp.974: The majority of people with Paget disease do not have symptoms. Those that do may experience bone pain, enlargement of the head, deafness, headache and bowing of the legs.
symp.975: Gradual loss of eyesight. Needing brighter light to read, increased blurry vision, increased problems reading, problems recognizing faces, a blind spot in the center of vision.
symp.976: DCIS often does not produce any symptoms. Occasionally, symptoms may include a breast lump or nipple discharge.
symp.977: Symptoms include involuntary muscle contractions that may produce repetitive movements (eye blinking), altered posture or an altered voice. Symptoms may worsen with fatigue or stress.
symp.978: Fatigue, pale skin, fast heart rate, shortness of breath, tingling in the feet and hands, decreased reflexes in the arms and legs, weakness, uncoordinated movements, diarrhea, bleeding gums, loss of smell, poor appetite.
symp.979: Scalp swelling, scalp tenderness, bleeding from ears, bruising behind the ears or under the eyes, unequal pupils, confusion, convulsions, difficulty with balance, drainage of clear fluid from ears or nose, excessive sleepiness, headache, loss of consciousness, nausea, restlessness, irritability, slurred speech, visual disturbances, vomiting.
symp.98: Watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, nausea, vomiting, fever, chills.
symp.980: Symptoms may include pain, lower leg deformity, inability to move the leg, leg swelling, numbness, and tenderness.
symp.981: Cough, shortness of breath, chest pain that often gets worse with deep breathing (pleuritic chest pain),  rapid breathing, rapid heart rate, blue discoloration of the skin (cyanosis), lightheadedness.
symp.982: Sudden onset of back pain, sudden onset of flank pain, bloody urine (hematuria).
symp.983: Tetanus should not occur if a person has been keeping up with regular tetanus immunization. Tetanus is a medical emergency.. Treatment options depend on the severity of the symptoms. If symptoms are mild, the infected wound is cleaned with debridement to avoid any further progression of the condition. Immune globin should be administered within 24 hours of onset of the symptoms. Immune globin contains antitoxin that neutralizes the tetanus toxin, helping to prevent any further penetration of the neurotoxin. Muscle spasms are also treated with common muscle relaxers such as diazepam (Valium). Antibiotics are given if the doctor suspects the bacteria producing the toxin still are alive. If more serious symptoms are present that affect the ability for the patient to breathe and/or swallow, the patient can be put on a breathing machine in the intensive care unit (ICU) until normal breathing returns. Symptoms on average may last 3-4 weeks, but complete rehabilitation may take several months. Once the condition begins to improve, shots are scheduled to restore tetanus immunity.
symp.984: Passage of gas or stool from the vagina, a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, recurrent vaginal or urinary tract infections, irritation or pain in the vagina, painful sexual intercourse, urgent bowel movements, inability to control bowel movements.
symp.985: Cracking, painful inflammation, weeping at the corners of the mouth.
symp.987: Frequent nasal crusting, nose bleeding, whistling while breathing, nasal obstruction, runny nose.
symp.988: Abdominal pain that is more intense than the tenderness, diarrhea, fever, vomiting, low blood pressure, abdominal distension, blood in the stool.
symp.989: Fatigue, frequent urination, increased thirst, fruity breath odor, confusion, coma, muscle stiffness or aching, nausea, vomiting, rapid breathing, shortness of breath.
symp.99: Injury to the skin causes: pain, redness, blistering, dehydration and a skin infection. Injury to the respiratory tract causes: cough, singed nasal hairs, shortness of breath, wheezing.
symp.991: Pelvic pain, pelvic tenderness, nausea, vomiting, sweating, diarrhea.
symp.992: Excessive hair loss from the scalp. The pattern of hair loss can help determine the cause. Scalp irritation can occur with hair treatment causes or with a fungal infection. Itching can also be experienced with a fungal infection.
symp.993: Pain, bleeding, a laceration that extends into the nail.
symp.994: Uterus is larger than expected for the dates in pregnancy, increased morning sickness, increased appetite, excessive weight gain, especially in early pregnancy, fetal movements felt in different parts of abdomen at same time.
symp.995: Pain, deformity, numbness, weakness, impaired motion.
symp.996: Pain, decreased motion, swelling, redness, tenderness.
symp.997: Fatigue, fever and chills, generalized itching, loss of appetite, night sweats, weight loss. Painless lymph node swelling in the neck, armpits and/or groin.
symp.998: They appear on the skin as raised, scaly spots on the skin. Rarely, do they itch or become painful.
symp.999: Pain, swelling, mild redness, bruising, tenderness, decreased motion, joint laxity, a feeling of instability.

Blood tests including a CBC, comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), urine analysis, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C- reactive protein (CRP) will be performed. Imaging tests are often needed, such as CT scans and/or an MRI. Diagnosis is usually confirmed by biopsy of the skin, a nerve or other involved tissue. 

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
Activated partial thromboplastin (aPTT or PTT)
Urinalysis (UA)
Hepatitis profile
Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)
Prothrombin test (PT, INR)
test.1297:
A history and physical exam will be performed. An MRI may be done to look for another cause of the symptoms or to help determine the need for surgery.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
test.1298:
A history and physical exam will be performed. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
Ultrasound
test.1299:
A history and physical exam will be performed. Usually the diagnosis can be made without additional testing. An X-ray, MRI or blood test may be performed to rule out other causes of pain.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
X-ray
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
test.13:
A history and physical exam will be performed. Other tests to determine the extent of disease include: nasogastric tube lavage, rectal exam, EGD (esophagogastroduodenoscopy), and blood tests.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
Electrocardiogram (EKG)
Lipase

Urea breath test (H. Pylori)
test.130:
A history and physical exam will be performed. Other tests to confirm the diagnosis and identify complications may be performed, including a barium enema or upper GI series, colonoscopy, CT scan or MRI. Stool tests may be recommended to check for blood or other causes of symptoms, such as infection.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
CT Scan
Lipase
X-ray
test.1300:
A history and physical will be done. Other tests may be performed to rule out a blockage of a coronary artery as the cause of the symptoms or other diseases of the heart such as an infection.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
Echocardiogram (ECHO)
Electrocardiogram (EKG)
Troponin
X-ray
test.1301:
A history and physical exam will be performed. A psychiatric evaluation may be recommended. Diagnostic testing may be recommended to rule out other causes for the symptoms.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
test.1302:
A history and physical exam will be performed. Blood tests, biopsies and culture of skin or other involved tissues may be done to identify the parasite. Other tests will be performed to identify the extent of involvement of the infection and to rule out other possible causes of symptoms. A special skin test, called the Montenegro skin test, can be helpful to identify an immune response to the parasite, an indication of prior exposure.



          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
CT Scan
Lipase
Urinalysis (UA)
X-ray
test.1303:

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
X-ray
test.1304:

Skin biopsy

test.132:

test.133:
A history and physical exam will be performed. Initial testing includes an electrocardiogram (EKG) and blood test for troponin (a heart muscle protein released into the blood if heart muscle damage has occurred). A coronary angiogram can identify the site of coronary artery blockage. A high resolution chest CT scan can also demonstrate blockages. CT scans can also rule out other diseases that can clinically mimic unstable angina. An echocardiogram may be done to see well the heart is pumping.

          	  Standard Workup:
          	
Complete blood count (CBC)
Comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)
Electrocardiogram (EKG)
X-ray
Cholesterol panel (LDL, HDL, total cholesterol, triglyceride)
